text:
- In In this video,
you'll see how to enable

post-launch actions in AWS
Elastic Disaster Recovery,
or AWS DRS.

With this feature, you
can automate actions

to run on your recovery
instances after they've launched.

You can choose to activate
predefined post-launch actions,
or create custom actions
for any AWS Systems Manager document.

This is the AWS Elastic
Disaster Recovery console.

Let's start by navigating to
default post-launch actions.

First, we'll install
the IAM roles required
to use post-launch actions.

Next, we'll change the Post-launch
action setting to Active.
This will enable post-launch settings
for newly-added source servers.

The Enable SSM action
is activated by default
and cannot be deactivated.
This action installs the AWS SSM agent
that is used to run post-launch actions

on recovery instances
after they are launched.
Next, let's go to the Source servers page.
We have one newly-added source server.
Let's look at its post-launch settings.
The server has inherited

the default post-launch
actions we just configured.
We can modify the settings

for this individual
source server at any time.
From here, we can add a custom action,

or we can choose predefined
actions to activate.
For demonstration purposes,

we'll activate the Linux
time sync setting action,
which will configure the recovery instance
to use the Amazon time sync service.

We'll keep the configuration
as is, and click Save.

Now, when we perform a recovery
job for the source server
and a recovery instance is launched,
the SSM agent will automatically install
on the recovery instance,

and the Linux time sync
setting will take effect.
Let's see this in action.
We'll initiate a recovery drill.

We can monitor the job from
the Recovery job history page.
The recovery job has completed.

To monitor the status of
the post-launch actions,

let's navigate to the
Recovery instances page

and select the newly-created
recovery instance.

The post-launch actions
finished successfully.
On the Post-launch action status tab

we get the status and
timestamps for each action,
as well as a link to the run logs.

You've just seen how to
enable post-launch actions
in AWS Elastic Disaster Recovery.

You can learn more about
this topic in the description
and links for this video.
Thanks for watching.
Now it's your turn to try.
